isis.stitle: TSI 04-08-07 - Instrument Cluster Individual Circuit Board Replacement

subjectgroup.subject: Instrument Cluster Individual Circuit Board Replacement

geninfo.para: Prior to this time the only way to make a repair to the Instrument Cluster was to replace the entire housing and circuit board assembly. It is now possible to replace only the problem circuit board, left, right, or center without replacing the entire assembly. Vehicles built prior to November 1997 should have center cluster boards with "Dip" switches as shown in Figure 6. After November 1997 they should have Data Link Clusters without the "Dip" switches. Removal and reinstallation of the cluster assembly has not changed; see Service Manual Section S08034 for the proper method of removing and reinstalling the cluster in the vehicle dash.

note.para: Left and right boards are designated as the cluster is viewed from the drivers seat.

warning.para: Batteries expel explosive gases. Keep sparks, flames, burning cigarettes, or other ignition sources away at all times. Always wear safety glasses and a face shield when working near batteries to avoid property damage, personal injury, or death.
To prevent electrical shock that could result in property damage, personal injury or death, always disconnect the negative battery terminal before working on the electrical system.

caution.para: Static electricity can cause permanent damage to the cluster. Before working with the cluster be sure to remove all static electricity from your body by touching the metal part of the dash.

item.para: Disconnect the negative battery terminal at the vehicle battery.
Remove the instrument cluster in accordance with Service Manual Section S08034.

Place the instrument cluster face down on a suitable smooth surface that will not scratch the cluster face as shown in Figure 1. Leave the front lens and gauge bezel in place in order to keep gauges located when the circuit boards are removed.

note.para: Circuit boards are labeled left and right as viewed from the drivers seat.

step1.para: Remove the five Phillips head screws shown in Figure 2.
Note whether or not there are gauges attached to the circuit board to be removed.
If there are no gauges attached simply lift the circuit board away from the housing.

step2.para: If there are gauges, carefully pry the circuit board upward from the cluster housing, move the pry device around the board so it raises equally on all sides until the gauge pins release the connectors attached to the circuit board.

step1.para: Remove the light holders from the board being replaced and install them into the replacement circuit board.

Carefully locate the new circuit board above the gauge pins (or mounting holes if no gauges are present) and uniformly push the new circuit board over the gauge pins until the new board is flat against the cluster housing.
Reinstall the five Phillips head screws previously removed. DO NOT OVER TORQUE THE SCREWS!
Remove the four Phillips head screws from the large circuit board shown in Figure 3.
Remove the two Phillips head screws from the small circuit board shown in Figure 3.
If there are no gauges attached simply lift the circuit boards away from the housing.

step2.para: If there are gauges, carefully pry the circuit board upward from the cluster housing, move the pry device around the board so it raises equally on all sides until the gauge pins release the connectors attached to the circuit board.

step1.para: The replacement large and small boards are molded together and must be cut apart prior to installation. DO NOT CUT THE TWO WIRES BETWEEN THE BOARDS!
Remove the light holders from the boards being replaced and install them into the correct locations on the replacement circuit boards.

Carefully locate the new large circuit board above the gauge pins (or mounting holes if no gauges are present) and uniformly push the new circuit board over the gauge pins until the new board is flat against the cluster housing.
Reinstall the four Phillips screws previously removed from the large circuit board and the two from the smaller board mounted above. DO NOT OVER TORQUE THE SCREWS!
Remove the six Phillips head screws holding the metal shield in place and remove the metal shield from the cluster as shown in Figure 4.
Remove the two remaining Phillips head screws under the metal shield removed in step 1. See Figure 5.

note.para:
Figure 5 shows a center circuit board for a vehicle built Nov. 1997 or after with a "Data Link" center circuit board and no "Dip" switches. Figure 6 shows a center board from a vehicle built before Nov. 1997 with "Dip" switches. If the cluster being replaced has "Dip" switches and all switches are set to "0" the cluster is the original unit and was programmed at the assembly plant. The replacement cluster is not factory programmed and will have to have the "Dip" switches set according to the "Dip" switch label on the old cluster. If the cluster being replaced has switches in positions other than "0", record the switch positions and set the replacement cluster "Dip" switches to the same position as the switches being replaced.
See Service Manual 08034x, INSTRUMENTS, SPEEDOMETER, MANUAL PROGRAMMING for specific instructions.

step1.para: Remove the electrical connectors attached to the odometer and/or hour meter located on the rear of the center circuit board.

Carefully pry up on the edges of the circuit board. The only thing attaching the board at this time are the pins from the gauges which are still being retained by the bezel and lens on the front of the cluster assembly. Once an edge is up continue to lift the board by prying near the gauge pins of the individual gauges. Once the circuit board is loose, carefully lift it from the cluster assembly making sure the odometer and/or hour meter feed wires and connectors exit through the holes in the board.
Place the hour/odometer leads through the holes in the new circuit board (Figure 5).

Install the new center board by carefully aligning the gauge pins to the circuit board holes and the mounting holes to the mounting studs on the cluster frame. Once in place carefully push the board down onto the gauge pins, making certain that the new board is flat against the cluster frame.
Reinstall the two Phillips head screws retaining the board to the cluster frame (Figure 5).

Remove the KPH/MPH jumper and/or the transmission gear resolution jumper from the old circuit board (used on center boards without "Dip" switches) and install in the same position on the new board as shown in Figure 5. See Service Manual Section S08155x for applications.
Reinstall the odometer and/or hour meter connectors to the pins on the circuit board.
Reinstall the metal shield over the centerboard and replace the six Phillips head screws removed in step 1. DO NOT OVER TORQUE THE SCREWS.
